title: Dictionary Methods and Operations
objectives: Master essential dictionary methods like .get(), .update(), and .pop()
Learn safe ways to access dictionary values without KeyError
Understand how to iterate over keys, values, and key-value pairs
Practice merging, copying, and clearing dictionaries

sections.title: The Concept
sections.content:
ğŸ”§ Dictionary Power Tools

Real-World Analogy First:

Think of a filing cabinet in an office:

  • ğŸ“‚ .get(): "Check if there's a file labeled 'Budget2024', but don't panic if it's missing - just tell me 'Not Found'"
  • ğŸ“‚ .update(): "Take all these files from that other cabinet and add them to this one"
  • ğŸ“‚ .pop(): "Remove the 'OldContract' file and hand it to me"
  • ğŸ“‚ .keys(): "Show me all the labels on the files"
  • ğŸ“‚ .values(): "Show me all the documents, without the labels"
  • ğŸ“‚ .items(): "Show me each label WITH its document"

These are the methods that make dictionaries incredibly powerful and flexible!

Now The Technical Terms:

Dictionary methods are built-in functions that perform common operations on dictionaries. They make your code safer, cleaner, and more efficient.

Why Methods Matter:

  • âœ… Safety: .get() prevents KeyError crashes
  • âœ… Convenience: .update() merges dictionaries in one line
  • âœ… Flexibility: .pop() removes and returns in one operation
  • âœ… Iteration: .keys(), .values(), .items() make looping easy

sections.title: Code Example
sections.content:
ğŸ’» Essential Dictionary Methods

Let's explore the most important dictionary methods:
sections.code:
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# EXAMPLE 1: .get() - Safe Value Access
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

print("Example 1: .get() method - safe access")
print()

person = {"name": "Alice", "age": 25}

# âŒ Direct access - crashes if key doesn't exist
try:
    email = person["email"]  # KeyError!
except KeyError:
    print("âŒ Direct access caused KeyError for missing 'email' key")

# âœ… .get() method - returns None if key doesn't exist
email = person.get("email")
print(f"âœ… .get() returned: {email} (no crash!)")

# âœ… .get() with default value
email = person.get("email", "no-email@example.com")
print(f"âœ… .get() with default: {email}")

# Works for existing keys too
name = person.get("name")
print(f"âœ… .get() for existing key: {name}")
print()

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# EXAMPLE 2: .keys(), .values(), .items()
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

print("Example 2: Accessing keys, values, and items")
print()

product = {
    "name": "Laptop",
    "price": 999.99,
    "brand": "TechCorp",
    "stock": 15
}

# Get all keys
print("All keys:")
for key in product.keys():
    print(f"  {key}")
print()

# Get all values
print("All values:")
for value in product.values():
    print(f"  {value}")
print()

# Get all key-value pairs
print("All key-value pairs:")
for key, value in product.items():
    print(f"  {key}: {value}")
print()

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# EXAMPLE 3: .update() - Merge Dictionaries
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

print("Example 3: .update() method - merging dictionaries")
print()

user = {"name": "Bob", "age": 30}
print(f"Original user: {user}")

# Update with new information
new_info = {"email": "bob@example.com", "city": "NYC"}
user.update(new_info)
print(f"After update: {user}")

# Update also modifies existing keys
changes = {"age": 31, "verified": True}
user.update(changes)
print(f"After second update: {user}")
print()

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# EXAMPLE 4: .pop() - Remove and Return
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

print("Example 4: .pop() method - remove and return")
print()

config = {
    "theme": "dark",
    "language": "en",
    "notifications": True,
    "beta_features": False
}

print(f"Original config: {config}")

# Remove and get the value
beta_setting = config.pop("beta_features")
print(f"\nRemoved beta_features: {beta_setting}")
print(f"Updated config: {config}")

# .pop() with default (won't crash if key missing)
volume = config.pop("volume", 50)  # Key doesn't exist, returns 50
print(f"\nPopped 'volume' (doesn't exist): {volume}")
print(f"Config unchanged: {config}")
print()

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# EXAMPLE 5: .setdefault() - Get or Create
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

print("Example 5: .setdefault() - get value or set default")
print()

user_prefs = {"theme": "light"}
print(f"Original preferences: {user_prefs}")

# Get existing value
theme = user_prefs.setdefault("theme", "dark")
print(f"Theme (exists): {theme}")
print(f"Prefs: {user_prefs}")  # Unchanged

# Set default for missing key
language = user_prefs.setdefault("language", "en")
print(f"\nLanguage (new): {language}")
print(f"Prefs: {user_prefs}")  # 'language' was added!
print()

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# EXAMPLE 6: .copy() and .clear()
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

print("Example 6: .copy() and .clear() methods")
print()

original = {"a": 1, "b": 2, "c": 3}
print(f"Original: {original}")

# Create a copy (separate dictionary)
copy = original.copy()
print(f"Copy: {copy}")

# Modify the copy
copy["a"] = 99
print(f"\nAfter modifying copy:")
print(f"  Copy: {copy}")
print(f"  Original: {original} (unchanged!)")

# Clear all items
copy.clear()
print(f"\nAfter clearing copy: {copy}")
print(f"Original still intact: {original}")
print()

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# EXAMPLE 7: Membership Testing with 'in'
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

print("Example 7: Checking if keys exist")
print()

inventory = {
    "apples": 50,
    "bananas": 30,
    "oranges": 40
}

# Check if key exists
if "apples" in inventory:
    print(f"âœ… We have {inventory['apples']} apples in stock")

if "grapes" in inventory:
    print("We have grapes")
else:
    print("âŒ No grapes in inventory")

# Check multiple items
needed_items = ["apples", "grapes", "bananas"]
print("\nChecking shopping list:")
for item in needed_items:
    if item in inventory:
        print(f"  âœ… {item}: {inventory[item]} available")
    else:
        print(f"  âŒ {item}: out of stock")
print()

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# EXAMPLE 8: Practical Use Case - Count Occurrences
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

print("Example 8: Counting items with .get()")
print()

votes = ["Alice", "Bob", "Alice", "Carol", "Bob", "Alice", "Dave", "Bob"]
print(f"Votes: {votes}")
print()

vote_count = {}
for name in votes:
    # Use .get() with default 0, then add 1
    vote_count[name] = vote_count.get(name, 0) + 1

print("Vote count:")
for person, count in vote_count.items():
    print(f"  {person}: {count} vote(s)")

# Find winner
winner = max(vote_count, key=vote_count.get)
print(f"\nğŸ† Winner: {winner} with {vote_count[winner]} votes!")
sections.output:
Example 1: .get() method - safe access

âŒ Direct access caused KeyError for missing 'email' key
âœ… .get() returned: None (no crash!)
âœ… .get() with default: no-email@example.com
âœ… .get() for existing key: Alice

Example 2: Accessing keys, values, and items

All keys:
  name
  price
  brand
  stock

All values:
  Laptop
  999.99
  TechCorp
  15

All key-value pairs:
  name: Laptop
  price: 999.99
  brand: TechCorp
  stock: 15

Example 3: .update() method - merging dictionaries

Original user: {'name': 'Bob', 'age': 30}
After update: {'name': 'Bob', 'age': 30, 'email': 'bob@example.com', 'city': 'NYC'}
After second update: {'name': 'Bob', 'age': 31, 'email': 'bob@example.com', 'city': 'NYC', 'verified': True}

Example 4: .pop() method - remove and return

Original config: {'theme': 'dark', 'language': 'en', 'notifications': True, 'beta_features': False}

Removed beta_features: False

Popped 'volume' (doesn't exist): 50

Example 5: .setdefault() - get value or set default

Original preferences: {'theme': 'light'}
Theme (exists): light
Prefs: {'theme': 'light'}

Language (new): en
Prefs: {'theme': 'light', 'language': 'en'}

Example 6: .copy() and .clear() methods

Original: {'a': 1, 'b': 2, 'c': 3}
Copy: {'a': 1, 'b': 2, 'c': 3}

After modifying copy:
  Copy: {'a': 99, 'b': 2, 'c': 3}
  Original: {'a': 1, 'b': 2, 'c': 3} (unchanged!)

After clearing copy: {}
Original still intact: {'a': 1, 'b': 2, 'c': 3}

Example 7: Checking if keys exist

âœ… We have 50 apples in stock
âŒ No grapes in inventory

Checking shopping list:
  âœ… apples: 50 available
  âŒ grapes: out of stock
  âœ… bananas: 30 available

Example 8: Counting items with .get()

Votes: ['Alice', 'Bob', 'Alice', 'Carol', 'Bob', 'Alice', 'Dave', 'Bob']

Vote count:
  Alice: 3 vote(s)
  Bob: 3 vote(s)
  Carol: 1 vote(s)
  Dave: 1 vote(s)

ğŸ† Winner: Alice with 3 votes!

sections.title: Syntax Breakdown
sections.content:
ğŸ” Understanding Dictionary Methods

Method 1: .get() - Safe Access

value = dictionary.get(key, default)
                       ^^^  ^^^^^^^  
                       key  optional default
  • ğŸ“Œ Returns value for key if it exists
  • ğŸ“Œ Returns None if key doesn't exist (no crash!)
  • ğŸ“Œ Returns default if provided and key doesn't exist
  • ğŸ“Œ NEVER raises KeyError
# Comparison
age = person["age"]          # âŒ KeyError if not exists
age = person.get("age")      # âœ… Returns None if not exists
age = person.get("age", 0)   # âœ… Returns 0 if not exists

Method 2: .keys() - Get All Keys

keys = dictionary.keys()
  • ğŸ“Œ Returns a view of all keys in the dictionary
  • ğŸ“Œ Can iterate over it: for key in dict.keys():
  • ğŸ“Œ Convert to list: list(dict.keys())
  • ğŸ“Œ Can check membership: "name" in dict.keys()

Method 3: .values() - Get All Values

values = dictionary.values()
  • ğŸ“Œ Returns a view of all values in the dictionary
  • ğŸ“Œ Can iterate: for value in dict.values():
  • ğŸ“Œ Can use with functions: max(dict.values())
  • ğŸ“Œ Values may include duplicates

Method 4: .items() - Get All Key-Value Pairs

items = dictionary.items()

# Most common use: iteration
for key, value in dictionary.items():
    print(f"{key}: {value}")
  • ğŸ“Œ Returns tuples of (key, value) pairs
  • ğŸ“Œ Perfect for iterating over entire dictionary
  • ğŸ“Œ Can unpack in loop: for k, v in dict.items():

Method 5: .update() - Merge Dictionaries

dictionary.update(other_dictionary)
dictionary.update({"key": "value"})  # Can use dict literal
  • ğŸ“Œ Adds all key-value pairs from other dictionary
  • ğŸ“Œ If key exists: overwrites with new value
  • ğŸ“Œ If key doesn't exist: adds it
  • ğŸ“Œ Modifies original dictionary (no return value)
user = {"name": "Alice", "age": 25}
user.update({"age": 26, "city": "NYC"})
# Result: {"name": "Alice", "age": 26, "city": "NYC"}
#         age updated ^^^      city added ^^^

Method 6: .pop() - Remove and Return

value = dictionary.pop(key, default)
                       ^^^  ^^^^^^^  
                       key  optional default
  • ğŸ“Œ Removes the key from dictionary
  • ğŸ“Œ Returns the value that was removed
  • ğŸ“Œ If key doesn't exist and no default: raises KeyError
  • ğŸ“Œ If key doesn't exist and default provided: returns default (no remove)
config = {"theme": "dark", "language": "en"}
theme = config.pop("theme")  # Returns "dark", removes from dict
# config is now: {"language": "en"}

volume = config.pop("volume", 50)  # Key doesn't exist, returns 50
# config unchanged: {"language": "en"}

Method 7: .setdefault() - Get or Initialize

value = dictionary.setdefault(key, default)
  • ğŸ“Œ If key exists: returns its value (like .get())
  • ğŸ“Œ If key doesn't exist: sets it to default AND returns default
  • ğŸ“Œ Useful for initializing nested structures
# Pattern for counting
count = {}
for item in items:
    count[item] = count.setdefault(item, 0) + 1
    #             ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^  
    #             Gets current count or sets to 0

Method 8: .copy() - Create Shallow Copy

new_dict = dictionary.copy()
  • ğŸ“Œ Creates a new dictionary with same key-value pairs
  • ğŸ“Œ Shallow copy: copies references, not nested objects
  • ğŸ“Œ Changes to copy don't affect original
  • ğŸ“Œ Changes to original don't affect copy

Method 9: .clear() - Remove All Items

dictionary.clear()
  • ğŸ“Œ Removes all key-value pairs
  • ğŸ“Œ Dictionary becomes empty {}
  • ğŸ“Œ Modifies in place (no return value)

Method 10: Membership Test with 'in'

if key in dictionary:
    # Key exists

if key not in dictionary:
    # Key doesn't exist
  • ğŸ“Œ Checks if key exists in dictionary
  • ğŸ“Œ Returns True or False
  • ğŸ“Œ Very fast operation (O(1))
  • ğŸ“Œ Only checks keys, not values!

Quick Reference Table:

MethodPurposeReturns
.get(k, d)Safe accessValue or default
.keys()All keysKey view
.values()All valuesValue view
.items()All pairsItem view
.update(d)Merge dictsNone
.pop(k, d)Remove & getValue or default
.setdefault(k, d)Get or createValue
.copy()DuplicateNew dict
.clear()Empty dictNone

sections.title: Exercise
sections.content:
âœï¸ Your Turn: Inventory Management System

Challenge: Create an inventory system using dictionary methods to manage product stock levels.

Starting Inventory:

inventory = {
    "apples": 50,
    "bananas": 30,
    "oranges": 40
}

Requirements:

  1. Add new products: Add "grapes" with quantity 25 and "mangoes" with 15 using a single .update() call
  2. Sale transaction: Someone buys 10 apples. Use .get() to safely decrease the count. If the item doesn't exist, print an error message.
  3. Check product availability: Use in keyword to check if "pineapple" is in inventory. If not, print a message.
  4. Remove discontinued item: Use .pop() to remove "oranges" from inventory and print how many were removed.
  5. Stock report: Use .items() to print all products with their quantities in a formatted way.
  6. Low stock alert: Use .items() to find and print items with quantity less than 20.
  7. Total items in stock: Use .values() to calculate the total number of items across all products.

Bonus: Create a function restock(product, amount) that uses .setdefault() to add products if they don't exist or increase stock if they do.
sections.starter_code:

inventory = {

}

print()

# Your code here

# Task 2: Process a sale (10 apples)

# Your code here

# Task 3: Check if pineapple is available
print("\nTask 3: Checking for pineapple...")
# Your code here

# Task 4: Remove oranges using .pop()
print("\nTask 4: Discontinuing oranges...")
# Your code here

# Task 5: Print stock report using .items()
print("\nTask 5: Stock Report")
print("â”€" * 50)
# Your code here

# Task 6: Low stock alert (< 20 items)
print("\nTask 6: Low Stock Alert")
print("â”€" * 50)
# Your code here

# Task 7: Calculate total items
print("\nTask 7: Total Inventory")
print("â”€" * 50)
# Your code here

# BONUS: Restock function
print("\nBONUS: Testing restock function")
print("â”€" * 50)

def restock(product, amount):
    # Your code here
    pass

# Test the function
# Your test code here

sections.title: Solution
sections.code:
# Starting inventory
inventory = {
    "apples": 50,
    "bananas": 30,
    "oranges": 40
}

print("ğŸ“¦ INVENTORY MANAGEMENT SYSTEM")
print("â•" * 50)
print(f"Starting inventory: {inventory}")
print()

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# Task 1: Add new products using .update()
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
print("Task 1: Adding new products...")
new_products = {"grapes": 25, "mangoes": 15}
inventory.update(new_products)
print(f"Added {list(new_products.keys())}")
print(f"Updated inventory: {inventory}")

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# Task 2: Process a sale (10 apples)
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
print("\nTask 2: Processing sale - 10 apples...")
product = "apples"
quantity_sold = 10

# Use .get() to safely access current stock
current_stock = inventory.get(product)

if current_stock is not None:
    if current_stock >= quantity_sold:
        inventory[product] = current_stock - quantity_sold
        print(f"âœ… Sold {quantity_sold} {product}")
        print(f"   Remaining: {inventory[product]}")
    else:
        print(f"âŒ Not enough {product} in stock!")
        print(f"   Available: {current_stock}, Requested: {quantity_sold}")
else:
    print(f"âŒ Product '{product}' not found in inventory!")

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# Task 3: Check if pineapple is available
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
print("\nTask 3: Checking for pineapple...")
if "pineapple" in inventory:
    print(f"âœ… Pineapple is available: {inventory['pineapple']} in stock")
else:
    print("âŒ Pineapple is not in our inventory")

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# Task 4: Remove oranges using .pop()
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
print("\nTask 4: Discontinuing oranges...")
oranges_removed = inventory.pop("oranges", 0)
print(f"Removed {oranges_removed} oranges from inventory")
print(f"Updated inventory: {inventory}")

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# Task 5: Print stock report using .items()
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
print("\nTask 5: Stock Report")
print("â”€" * 50)
print(f"{'Product':<15} {'Quantity':>10}")
print("â”€" * 50)
for product, quantity in inventory.items():
    print(f"{product.capitalize():<15} {quantity:>10}")
print("â”€" * 50)

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# Task 6: Low stock alert (< 20 items)
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
print("\nTask 6: Low Stock Alert")
print("â”€" * 50)
low_stock_items = []
for product, quantity in inventory.items():
    if quantity < 20:
        low_stock_items.append((product, quantity))
        print(f"âš ï¸  {product.capitalize()}: Only {quantity} remaining!")

if not low_stock_items:
    print("âœ… All items are well stocked")
else:
    print(f"\nTotal low stock items: {len(low_stock_items)}")

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# Task 7: Calculate total items
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
print("\nTask 7: Total Inventory")
print("â”€" * 50)
total_items = sum(inventory.values())
product_count = len(inventory)
average_stock = total_items / product_count if product_count > 0 else 0

print(f"Total products: {product_count}")
print(f"Total items in stock: {total_items}")
print(f"Average stock per product: {average_stock:.1f}")

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# BONUS: Restock function
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
print("\nBONUS: Testing restock function")
print("â”€" * 50)

def restock(product, amount):
    """Restock a product, adding it if it doesn't exist.
    
    Args:
        product: Product name
        amount: Quantity to add
    
    Returns:
        New total quantity
    """
    # Use .setdefault() to get current value or initialize to 0
    current = inventory.setdefault(product, 0)
    new_total = current + amount
    inventory[product] = new_total
    
    if current == 0:
        print(f"  â• Added new product '{product}': {amount} units")
    else:
        print(f"  ğŸ“¦ Restocked '{product}': {current} + {amount} = {new_total}")
    
    return new_total

# Test the restock function
print("\nRestocking operations:")
restock("apples", 20)      # Existing product
restock("pineapple", 30)   # New product
restock("bananas", 15)     # Existing product

print("\n" + "â•" * 50)
print("FINAL INVENTORY")
print("â•" * 50)
for product, quantity in sorted(inventory.items()):
    status = "âš ï¸ LOW" if quantity < 20 else "âœ…"
    print(f"{status} {product.capitalize():<15} {quantity:>10}")

print("â•" * 50)
print(f"Grand Total: {sum(inventory.values())} items across {len(inventory)} products")
print("â•" * 50)

sections.explanation:
ğŸ“š How Each Part Works:

  1. Task 1 - .update() for Bulk Adding (Lines 16-19):
    new_products = {"grapes": 25, "mangoes": 15}
inventory.update(new_products)
    • Create a dictionary with new products
    • .update() adds all key-value pairs at once
    • More efficient than adding one by one
  2. Task 2 - Safe Access with .get() (Lines 26-38):
    current_stock = inventory.get(product)
if current_stock is not None:
    • .get() returns None if key doesn't exist (no crash!)
    • Check if stock exists before processing
    • Can also check if enough stock before sale
    • Update the value after validation
  3. Task 3 - Membership Check with 'in' (Lines 44-48):
    if "pineapple" in inventory:
    • Fast way to check if key exists
    • Returns True or False
    • Clearer than try/except for this use case
  4. Task 4 - Remove with .pop() (Lines 54-57):
    oranges_removed = inventory.pop("oranges", 0)
    • .pop() removes AND returns the value
    • Second argument (0) is default if key doesn't exist
    • Two operations in one: remove + get value
  5. Task 5 - Iterate with .items() (Lines 63-68):
    for product, quantity in inventory.items():
    • .items() returns (key, value) pairs
    • Unpack into two variables in the loop
    • Most common way to loop over dictionaries
  6. Task 6 - Filter Using .items() (Lines 74-82):
    for product, quantity in inventory.items():
    if quantity < 20:
    • Loop through all items
    • Filter by checking a condition on values
    • Collect items that match criteria
  7. Task 7 - Sum with .values() (Line 89):
    total_items = sum(inventory.values())
    • .values() returns all values
    • sum() adds them up
    • Clean, one-line calculation
  8. BONUS - .setdefault() Pattern (Lines 101-113):
    current = inventory.setdefault(product, 0)
new_total = current + amount
inventory[product] = new_total
    • .setdefault() gets value OR creates with default
    • If product exists: returns current stock
    • If product doesn't exist: adds it with value 0
    • Then add the restock amount

âš ï¸ Common Mistakes:

  1. Not Checking if .get() Returned None:
    # âŒ WRONG - will crash if key doesn't exist
stock = inventory.get("apples")
stock = stock - 10  # TypeError if stock is None!

# âœ… CORRECT - check first
stock = inventory.get("apples")
if stock is not None:
    stock = stock - 10
  2. Forgetting Default in .pop():
    # âŒ WRONG - KeyError if key doesn't exist
value = inventory.pop("missing_item")

# âœ… CORRECT - provide default
value = inventory.pop("missing_item", 0)
  3. Modifying Dict While Iterating:
    # âŒ WRONG - can cause RuntimeError
for product in inventory:
    if inventory[product] < 10:
        inventory.pop(product)  # Modifying while iterating!

# âœ… CORRECT - iterate over copy
for product in list(inventory.keys()):
    if inventory[product] < 10:
        inventory.pop(product)
  4. Confusing .update() and Assignment:
    # .update() MODIFIES the original
original = {"a": 1}
original.update({"b": 2})
# original is now {"a": 1, "b": 2}

# Assignment REPLACES
original = {"a": 1}
original = {"b": 2}
# original is now {"b": 2} only!

ğŸ’¡ Pro Tips:

  • âœ… Use .get() with defaults: count = scores.get(player, 0) prevents crashes
  • âœ… .items() for iteration: Most readable way to loop over dictionaries
  • âœ… .pop() with default: Safe removal that won't crash
  • âœ… .update() for merging: Clean way to combine dictionaries
  • âœ… 'in' for existence checks: Faster and clearer than try/except
  • âœ… .setdefault() for initialization: Perfect for counters and accumulators

sections.title: Key Takeaways
sections.content:
ğŸ¯ Essential Points to Remember:

  1. .get() - Safe value access (prevents KeyError):
    value = dict.get(key, default)
# Returns value if key exists, default otherwise
    • NEVER raises KeyError
    • Returns None if no default specified
    • Returns default if key doesn't exist
  2. .keys(), .values(), .items() - Access dict contents:
    dict.keys()    # All keys
dict.values()  # All values
dict.items()   # All (key, value) pairs
    • Return views (not lists, but can iterate)
    • Use .items() for looping: for k, v in dict.items():
    • Convert to list if needed: list(dict.keys())
  3. .update() - Merge dictionaries:
    dict1.update(dict2)
# Adds all items from dict2 to dict1
# Overwrites existing keys, adds new ones
    • Modifies the original dictionary
    • Returns None (modifies in place)
  4. .pop() - Remove and return:
    value = dict.pop(key, default)
# Removes key and returns its value
    • Removes the key-value pair
    • Returns the value
    • Provide default to prevent KeyError
  5. .setdefault() - Get or initialize:
    value = dict.setdefault(key, default)
# If key exists: returns value
# If not: sets key=default and returns default
    • Useful for initializing nested structures
    • Common in counting patterns
  6. .copy() - Duplicate dictionary:
    new_dict = original.copy()
# Creates separate dictionary
    • Changes to copy don't affect original
    • Shallow copy (nested objects are referenced)
  7. .clear() - Remove all items:
    dict.clear()
# Dictionary becomes empty {}
  8. 'in' keyword - Check if key exists:
    if key in dict:
    # Key exists
if key not in dict:
    # Key doesn't exist
    • Fast operation (O(1))
    • Checks keys only, not values
  9. Method comparison table:
    When you need to...Use this
    Get value safely.get(key, default)
    Loop over all items.items()
    Merge dictionaries.update(other)
    Remove and get value.pop(key, default)
    Check if key existskey in dict
    Initialize if missing.setdefault(key, default)
    Make a copy.copy()
  10. Common patterns:
    # Counting pattern
for item in items:
    count[item] = count.get(item, 0) + 1

# Default initialization
data[key] = data.setdefault(key, [])
data[key].append(value)

# Safe removal
removed = dict.pop('key', None)
if removed:
    print(f"Removed {removed}")

ğŸš€ Coming Up Next:

In the next lesson, you'll learn about Nested Dictionaries - how to store complex, hierarchical data like databases of students with courses and grades, or JSON-like structures!

checkpoint_quiz.question: What does dict.get('key', 'default') return if 'key' doesn't exist?
checkpoint_quiz.explanation: dict.get('key', 'default') returns 'default' if the key doesn't exist. This is the whole point of .get() - it provides a safe way to access values with a fallback. Without the second argument, it would return None. It never raises KeyError.

checkpoint_quiz.question: Which method should you use to iterate over both keys AND values in a dictionary?
checkpoint_quiz.explanation: .items() returns (key, value) pairs, perfect for iteration: 'for key, value in dict.items()'. .keys() only gives keys, .values() only gives values, and .pairs() doesn't exist. .items() is the most common way to loop over dictionaries.

checkpoint_quiz.question: What does dict.pop('key', 0) do if 'key' exists in the dictionary?
options: Removes the key and returns its value
Returns the value but doesn't remove the key
checkpoint_quiz.explanation: .pop('key', 0) REMOVES the key from the dictionary AND RETURNS its value (if the key exists). The 0 is only used as a default if the key doesn't exist. So if key exists, it's removed and its value is returned. If it doesn't exist, it returns 0 without error.
